awd_titl_txt: Large Area High Quality, Electron Cyclotron Resonance       Chemical Vapor Deposition SiC Thin Films for Astronomical   Mirrors
awd_abstract_narration: Silicon carbide is a leading new candidate for mirror blanks                    because of its high stiffness, relatively high thermal                          conductivity, and abrasion resistance.  This base material contains             pores or large grains, which make it difficult to provide a smooth              front surface.  A process has been developed for using electron                 cyclotron resonance chemical vapor deposition to deposit very                   smooth amorphous silicon carbide (SiC) on 100 mm substrates.  This              material is easily polished to obtain a 10-20A rms surface                      roughness.  This process will be scaled up to coat large diameter               optics.  The main problems associated with scale up involved plasma             gas dynamics and fluid flows.  As part of this program, we will                 develop a general computational model that will be used for                     designing the gas delivery system.  We will then modify an existing             system to coat large-area optics with smooth, amorphous SiC.
